title: Should we use emojis in books? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely not. If you can’t say what you mean to say without using an emoji, you are not a good writer.

Thanks for the A2A Should we use emojis in books? Probably not. Unless you are doing something special, specifically related to emojis or the use of them or the culture around them, or even a kids’ book made out of them, I would not. If I were to pick up a history book that was written with emojis, I would immediately put it back. Same for a math book, a current events non-fiction, or anything that wasn’t supposed to be frivolous. There is already a feeling by many people that today’s culture is one of, shall we say, ignorance? For lack of a better term. It seems that not only do many people no longer know how to write in a formal or proper manner, but that they don’t even care that they do not. I would read a short story with emojis, if it were well done. I don’t think I could tolerate a novel. I would not read a news article or anything supposed to be informative. I know this is a bias, and I don’t like to have those, but that really, to me, screams that the writer thinks they are too good to learn how to do things the right way, and they don’t care what other people think. Now, in my defense, there is a problem with emojis. They don’t mean anything specific. Or rather, they mean whatever people want them to mean. It is like abstract art. What exactly does an $1.4 million dollar painting automatically going into a shredder upon purchase mean? I’m pretty sure it doesn’t mean the same thing to the artist as it did to the buyer. Watch This $1.4 Million Banksy Painting Shred Itself As Soon As It's Sold The same can be said of emojis. My daughter asked me why I kept sending her “hugs”. I told her I thought it meant “excited”. There are more examples, but I won’t bore with them. My point is, they mean different things to different people, which means you cannot communicate clearly with them. At least not until universal established meanings are set and agreed upon. It may be fun to play games with emojis, but I’d hate to try to argue a case in court with one. Clearly conveyed complicated ideas are not only not guaranteed, they are not likely between strangers at all. I wouldn’t recommend using them in most kinds of books.
